column5: Anyone have any recommendations for a lightweight trailer jack? My boat, loaded including motor, probably weighs 1500 pounds.
Go to a car salvage yard and get a used scissor jack...light and easy to stow.
Northern Tool/Tractor Supply/Fleet Farm etc under $30
I have several car jacks which work very well. If you go to many garage sales, they seem to be fairly abundant, at least in my area. Bill
https://www.tirerack.com/accessories/detail.jsp?ID=67 Aluminum. Low profile. Not too heavy. Stays in my truck. I have seen like models sold other places.

I bought a new scissors jack from Farm & Fleet couple years ago. Welded a nut on the shaft you crank. Now use an electric impact to raise and lower it. I carry the battery impact (Milwaukee 3/8) for changing flats so figured why not use it to also raise the jack. Also carry a 2x12 to use as a base under the jack to stabilize it. I also put a light lithium grease on the threads as the impact isn't smooth when raising the trailer.The jack is not heavy duty enough for lifting the truck if needed.Just another thought/option.Pooch

That is the same jack sold under many different names. We have one for our race car. Good little jack, but takes up a lot of room to store. Just don't lift a heavy 3/4 ton truck with one. They are over rated.pooch

Whatever jack you get, test it at home to make sure that it's up to the task. 300 miles from home is no place to find out that it won't work. Also carry a few pieces of 2" × 6" or 2" × 8" in case of having to jack on soft ground. andersaki
Definitely carry some various wooden pieces for a jack base. Bill
